title: Donald Trump made promise to Harry Dunn's mother after she squeezed his hand
text:

Donald Trump made a promise to Harry Dunn's mother after she squeezed his hand during their White House meeting.

Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn, the parents of the late teenager, met the US President in a bid to get justice after Harry's death in a head-on collision outside RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire in August.

They refused to meet Anne Sacoolas, the motorist allegedly responsible for the crash, who was given diplomatic immunity and allowed to return to the US after the crash.

Trump told Harry's grieving parents that Sacoolas would not return to the UK - but promised he would "try another avenue" to help them.

Speaking on today's Good Morning Britain, Charlotte admitted the President was "sincere" and had given her hope of a "little positive" outcome.

(Image: ITV)

(Image: Justice4Harry)

She said: "It was during the main meeting I spoke directly to him for a good few minutes, he did seem sincere, he did seem to listen to me very well, he didn’t try to interrupt me or cut me off.

"I explained to him how much grief we’ve got locked away and how we feel it was very inhumane for her to have left the UK and come back to the USA.

"I wanted answers as to who made that decision, why did they think that was the right decision, what date she actually left, unfortunately I didn’t get any of those answers."

(Image: ITV)

She continued: "At the end of the meeting when we were all leaving the room. He shook all of our hands again. I was last in line, it was actually him that took my hand and I squeezed it very tight.

"I said to him, ‘If this was your son, surely you’d be doing the same thing and be trying to get justice for him?’ And he agreed with me and he said, ‘Yes, yes I would’.

"I said, ‘So please, please just do the right thing, just please try’ and he squeezed my hand back and he said he would try to push another way forward, sorry, try and ‘look at this from another angle’ was what he said.

"I don’t really know what he meant by that, I don’t know what timescale or whatever other angle he’s going to look into. It felt sincere enough for me to be able to feel we’d come out with a little positive.

"But if I’m totally honest, I don’t hold out too much hope that she’s going to be returned to us in the UK."

(Image: ITV)

Charlotte added: "I think we’re just going to just be forever disappointed, forever disgusted in both the UK and US governments. It just doesn’t make sense to us as to why on earth this should be allowed to happen. It should have been a very clear-cut case.

"But we promised Harry that night in the hospital after we lost him, we stayed with him for as long as we could, and we promised that we’d try and get justice for him thinking it was going to be simple. We didn’t embark on this without putting some really good thought into it. He would have done the same for anyone of us.

"We owe it to him to honour him and do our absolute best to get justice for Harry. If that doesn’t come in the way we want it, we will continue to work and we will try and get those diplomatic laws looked at."

(Image: SKY NEWS)

Radd Seiger, the Dunn family spokesperson, explained they had lots of legal options.

He added: “Be under no illusion that we have a number of legal options open to us to try and get justice for Harry. We don’t want to do that, but behind the scenes, there is an awful lot of work going on preparing major legal proceedings on both sides of the Atlantic. We strongly believe this lady did not have immunity, she should not have gone and she should come back.”

Asked if she could speak to Anne mother-to-mother and what she’d say, Charlotte said: “I would just ask her to get on the plane and do the humane thing, do the right thing, set her children a good example.

“She needs to do the right thing and make that decision herself to get back on the plane and come back to the UK and meet us on UK soil and face what she’s actually done.”

(Image: ITV)

Good Morning Britain viewers took to Twitter after the interview to praise Charlotte.

One viewer said: "What powerful heartbreaking TV. The way Harry’s Mum spoke. Come on @realDonaldTrump get Anne Sacoolas back to the UK"

Another added: "Watching the interview on #gmb with Harry Dunn’s mum and it’s heartbreaking!"

A third said: "Harry Dunn's mum on #gmb.What a brave and superb woman and mother.This family deserve justice."

*Good Morning Britain airs weekdays on ITV at 6am
description: The US President gave Charlotte Charles hope of a 'little positive' outcome after she pleaded for justice after the death of her 19-year-old son
